Time in Machine Learning Engineering â³ - A Faux-Calculus Argument

A witty and not-so-rigorous attempt to demonstrate the often-overlooked importance of time in ML projects that will annoy most mathematicians and alienate some physicists!

Time in Software Engineering

Thereâ€™s a saying at Google (Winters et al., 2020) that Software Engineering or SWE for short is just

"programming integrated over time"

Now, I love taking things too literally and seeing how far I can go. Thatâ€™s just how I roll, with utter disregard for the consequences of my deductions.

Having said that, we can represent the assertion above using a very simple formula

SWEÂ =Â âˆ«ProgrammingÂ dt \texttt{SWE} ~=~ \int \texttt{Programming} ~dt SWEÂ =Â âˆ«ProgrammingÂ dt

For lack of a better name, Iâ€™ll call this method of using calculus (or something close to it) to represent catchy slogans and witty remarks â€œFaux Calculusâ€.

Getting back to the main argument, if thereâ€™s one key insight we can take from this is that SWE is more than just writing codeâ€Šâ€“â€Šitâ€™s about maintaining that code over time.

In fact, engineering in general is mostly about creating things that will stand the test of time. And we often use expressions like â€œfuture-proofâ€, â€œlong-termâ€ and â€œreliableâ€ to stress how important it is to build lasting solutions and tools.

In that sense, engineering can be described as a functional (high-order operator in CS terms) involving a time integral

fâ†¦E[f]=âˆ«fÂ dt f \mapsto \texttt{E}[f] = \int f ~dt fâ†¦E[f]=âˆ«fÂ dt

which we can represent as fEf\texttt{E}fE using a postfix notation, so that SWE\texttt{SWE}SWE is really just E[SW]\texttt{E}[\texttt{SW}]E[SW].

â€œOkâ€ I hear you say â€œThese formulas are cool and allâ€ (if youâ€™re a working mathematician, youâ€™re probably shouting at the screen and pulling your own hair at this point) â€œBut why are we making such a big fuss about time? What makes it so important?â€

Well, Iâ€™m glad you asked!

In case you havenâ€™t noticed, time changes everything âŒ› Just read Percy Bysshe Shelley poem Ozymandias!

In the world of SW development, the effects of the passage of time are especially dire:

  • Developers come and go
  • Programming languages go out of style
  • Frameworks go out of date
  • Features turn old and obsolete (or worse, irrelevant)
  • Code begets legacy code
  • Documentationâ€¦ well, donâ€™t get me started on documentation.

In the midst of all this chaos, the only solutions that thrive and prosper are the ones that react and adapt to change in a timely manner.

The ones that donâ€™t, the ones that choose the easy way, the â€œroad most travelledâ€, start to accrue debtâ€¦ of the technical kind.

Donâ€™t you just love a good economical metaphor, dear reader?

Unlike the Graeberian notion of debt as a â€œpreversion of a promiseâ€ (Graeber, 2011), technical debt is non-negotiable and it needs to be repaid in full if a project intends to keep the lights on. This entails keeping up with all the â€œpromisesâ€ made by the PM to the stakeholders when writing the project charter and by the SW engineers when documenting their code.

Time in MachineÂ Learning Engineering

Technical debt is also lurking behind any ML project.

In a paper presented at NeurIPS and provocatively titled, â€œHidden Technical Debt in Machine Learning Systemsâ€, Sculley et al. (2015) argued that there are no â€œquick winsâ€ in real-world ML systems and that nothing ever comes for â€œfreeâ€.

Their simple representation of a ML system as a disjoint set of â€œboxesâ€ is probably one of the most used images in the whole MLE and MLOps literature. And for good reasons.

It illustrates two very important facts about real-world ML: 1/ how complex ML development really is and 2/ how small the â€œcool stuffâ€ (ML code) is compared to everything else AKA â€œplumbingâ€ (data, infrastructure, &c.).

Failing to acknowledge either 1 or 2 (and its consequences) will lead any promising ML endeavour to spiral out of control and crash. According to a recent Gartner report, around 90% of all AI and ML projects fail to deliver, and only half of them make it to production.

Can we invert this tendency? Something needs to changeâ€¦ but what?

In the remainder of this article, Iâ€™ll argue, using the same faux-calculus reasoning we applied to SWE, that ML practitioners everywhere should handle time more carefully, and explore what that means for Machine Learning Engineering (MLE).

Letâ€™s start with the basicsâ€¦

Nowadays, when delivering an â€˜Intro to MLâ€™ (ML101) presentation, it has become standard practice to include a slide comparing traditional programming and ML, and stating just how much of a â€˜paradigm shiftâ€™ it is to go from one to the other (Thomas Kuhn is probably rolling in his grave ğŸª¦).

Something along the lines of

or, focusing only on the ML side of the spectrum

These are often abbreviated as

MLÂ =Â Code+Data \texttt{ML} ~=~ \texttt{Code} + \texttt{Data} MLÂ =Â Code+Data

For most ML applications, however, this picture is too simplistic.

A better alternative involves the notion of 3 axis of change first put forward in Martin Fowlerâ€™s Continuous Delivery for ML (CD4ML) article

which can be summarized as

MLÂ =Â Code+Data+Model \texttt{ML} ~=~ \texttt{Code} + \texttt{Data} + \texttt{Model} MLÂ =Â Code+Data+Model

You probably see where Iâ€™m going with this, right?

Letâ€™s apply the engineering (E\texttt{E}E) operator we defined above to our new definition

MLEÂ =Â âˆ«Code+Data+ModelÂ dt \texttt{MLE} ~=~ \int \texttt{Code} + \texttt{Data} + \texttt{Model} ~dt MLEÂ =Â âˆ«Code+Data+ModelÂ dt

We can translate this into something more readable

MLE is just a bunch of stuff summed up together, integrated over time

Sounds ominous, doesnâ€™t it?

Too bad itâ€™s dead wrong!

As any freshman calculus student knows (and, integration-wise, thatâ€™s probably the only thing most of them know by the time they graduate), the sum rule of Integration tells us that

The integral of the sum is the sum of the integrals

So, what our formula is telling us is that

MLEÂ =Â âˆ«CodeÂ dt+âˆ«DataÂ dt+âˆ«ModelÂ dt \texttt{MLE} ~=~ \int \texttt{Code} ~dt + \int \texttt{Data} ~dt + \int \texttt{Model} ~dt MLEÂ =Â âˆ«CodeÂ dt+âˆ«DataÂ dt+âˆ«ModelÂ dt

If we equate Code\texttt{Code}Code with Programming\texttt{Programming}Programming (which is debatable to be sure, but letâ€™s keep with it for now), then weâ€™re basically saying that

MLE is just good old SWE, data engineering and something we don't yet know what to call or how to handle, summed up together

which is a gross oversimplificationâ€¦ and a flat out lie.

By the way, just in case youâ€™re wondering about this, Iâ€™m assuming that every term in that integral has an explicit time dependence. Schematically, this can be represented as

DataÂ =Â Data(t) \texttt{Data} ~=~ \texttt{Data}(t) DataÂ =Â Data(t)

ModelÂ =Â Model(t) \texttt{Model} ~=~ \texttt{Model}(t) ModelÂ =Â Model(t)

CodeÂ =Â Code(t) \texttt{Code} ~=~ \texttt{Code}(t) CodeÂ =Â Code(t)

If this were not the case, then each one of these â€œtermsâ€, at least with respect to time, would be a trivial matter to solve.

So whatâ€™s wrong with this line of reasoning? And how, if at all, can we fix it?

There are two main issues with our initial approach: one is foundational, the other one is holistic.

The first problem is that the definitions given above donâ€™t take into account the close dependencies between the 3 axis of change.

Model\texttt{Model}Model relies heavily on the quality of the Data\texttt{Data}Data used for training, validation and testing - the old â€œGarbage In, Garbage Outâ€ (GIGO) dictum. On the other hand, Code\texttt{Code}Code adapts both to the Model\texttt{Model}Model used for inference and the Data\texttt{Data}Data that we feed into it.

DataÂ =Â Data(t) \texttt{Data} ~=~ \texttt{Data}(t) DataÂ =Â Data(t)

ModelÂ =Â Model(Data,t) \texttt{Model} ~=~ \texttt{Model}(\texttt{Data}, t) ModelÂ =Â Model(Data,t)

CodeÂ =Â Code(Data,Model,t) \texttt{Code} ~=~ \texttt{Code}(\texttt{Data}, \texttt{Model}, t) CodeÂ =Â Code(Data,Model,t)

The question of whether Model\texttt{Model}Model depends explicitly on time is a matter of philosophical debate.

Using the Chain rule we can start asking some deep questions about any ML system:

1/ How is the Data\texttt{Data}Data changing over time?

dÂ Datadt \frac{d~\texttt{Data}}{d t} dtdÂ Dataâ€‹

Food for thought: Can we distinguish data drift (XXX changes) from concept drift (Xâ†’yX \rightarrow yXâ†’y changes) within this framework?

2/ What is the best way to deal with Model\texttt{Model}Model drift?

dÂ Modeldt=âˆ‚Â Modelâˆ‚Â DatadÂ Datadt+âˆ‚Â Modelâˆ‚t \frac{d~\texttt{Model}}{d t} = \frac{\partial~\texttt{Model}}{\partial~\texttt{Data}} \frac{d~\texttt{Data}}{d t} + \frac{\partial~\texttt{Model}}{\partial t} dtdÂ Modelâ€‹=âˆ‚Â Dataâˆ‚Â Modelâ€‹dtdÂ Dataâ€‹+âˆ‚tâˆ‚Â Modelâ€‹

3/ Can Code\texttt{Code}Code be decoupled from Model\texttt{Model}Model changes?

dÂ Codedt=âˆ‚Â Codeâˆ‚Â DatadÂ Datadt+âˆ‚Â Codeâˆ‚Â ModeldÂ Modeldt+âˆ‚Â Codeâˆ‚t \frac{d~\texttt{Code}}{d t} = \frac{\partial~\texttt{Code}}{\partial~\texttt{Data}} \frac{d~\texttt{Data}}{d t} + \cancel{\frac{\partial~\texttt{Code}}{\partial~\texttt{Model}}} \frac{d~\texttt{Model}}{d t} + \frac{\partial~\texttt{Code}}{\partial t} dtdÂ Codeâ€‹=âˆ‚Â Dataâˆ‚Â Codeâ€‹dtdÂ Dataâ€‹+âˆ‚Â Modelâˆ‚Â Codeâ€‹â€‹dtdÂ Modelâ€‹+âˆ‚tâˆ‚Â Codeâ€‹

Finally, thereâ€™s the (erroneous) assumption that we can just sum everything up and call it a day.

Reality is probably closer to something closer to this

MLEÂ =Â âˆ«ideaEOLL(Data,Model,Code,Dataâ€²,Modelâ€²,Codeâ€²,t)Â dt \texttt{MLE} ~=~ \int^{EOL}_{idea} L(\texttt{Data}, \texttt{Model}, \texttt{Code}, \texttt{Data}', \texttt{Model}', \texttt{Code}', t) ~dt MLEÂ =Â âˆ«ideaEOLâ€‹L(Data,Model,Code,Dataâ€²,Modelâ€²,Codeâ€²,t)Â dt

where the prime (â€˜) represents a derivative w.r.t. time (ttt) and EOL (end-of-life) indicates the inevitable demise of the ML system, hopefully at a point far into the future.

The actual form of LLL is usually unknown, most likely problem-dependent.

The takeaway message is that the dynamics of MLE is something really tricky, not to be triffled with.

If youâ€™re a physics nerd like me, you probably noticed that I called that function LLL (*wink *wink *nudge *nudge).

Without getting into variational calculus, a clear analogy can be made between MLE\texttt{MLE}MLE and the principle of stationary action

Î´Â MLE=0 \delta~\texttt{MLE} = 0 Î´Â MLE=0

Iâ€™m just not sure what to make of it yet!

To be continuedâ€¦

Defect Detection with Amazon Lookout for Vision

Last re:Invent, AWS announced the release of a handful of products and services geared towards helping industrial customers and partners in their journey to digital transformation.

Under the umbrella term of AWS for Industrial, these offerings, which include not only services e.g. Amazon Lookout for Equipment but also devices e.g. Amazon Monitron and full-blown solutions e.g. Amazon SageMaker for Predictive Maintenance, cover a myriad of interesting use-cases and industry-relevant workloads in such areas as Production & Asset Optimization and Quality Management.

In this article, we give an introduction to AWS for Industrial through one of its core services - Amazon Lookout for Vision - a service that treats the defect detection problem as a simple binary (image) classification task.

Machine Learning for Medicine and Healthcare ğŸ‘¨â€âš•ï¸

The ubiquity of algorithms and data is one of the hallmarks of the Information Age. In a world powered by technology, where smartphones have more computing power than all of NASAâ€™s computers during the Apollo missions, algorithms run virtually everything.

However, in the advent of the 4th Industrial Revolution, data is growing faster than it can be analyzed and classic algorithms have been unable to cope with this Big Data explosion. This is where Artificial Intelligence (AI), and Machine Learning (ML) in particular, really shine.

ML systems learn directly from data without being explicitly told to do so, and they have found enormous success in such tasks as email filtering, computer-aided diagnostics (CADx) and autonomous driving. Companies like Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google are investing heavily on AI, and ML engineer and data scientist positions are among the highest paid and â€œsexiestâ€ jobs of the early 21st century. Nonetheless, getting past the hype and putting buzzwords aside is hard when one lacks a basic understanding of how these systems actually work. This is especially relevant in the health sector where transparency and accountability are of paramount importance.

In this workshop, we give an overview of ML that highlights some of its applications to the health sector - from the rise of expert systems in the 80s to the diagnosis, prognosis and treatment of SARSâ€‘CoVâ€‘2 - how it is shaping the present and how it may one day decide our future.
